channel.title: NYT > Technology
channel.copyright: Copyright 2026 The New York Times Company

item.title: Homeland Security Demands Social Media Sites Reveal Names Behind Anti-ICE Posts
item.description: The department has sent Google, Meta and other companies hundreds of subpoenas for information on accounts that track or comment on Immigration and Customs Enforcement, officials and tech workers said.
item.dc:creator: Sheera Frenkel and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Department of Homeland Security is expanding its efforts to identify Americans who oppose Immigration and Customs Enforcement.

item.title: Meta Plans to Add Facial Recognition Technology to Its Smart Glasses
item.description: In an internal memo last year, Meta said the political tumult in the United States would distract critics from the feature’s release.
item.dc:creator: Kashmir Hill, Kalley Huang and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Lucia Vazquez for The New York Times
item.media:description: The maker of Meta’s smart glasses said it sold more than seven million pairs last year.

item.title: Iran Turns to Digital Surveillance Tools to Track Down Protesters
item.description: As Iranian authorities restore some online services after crushing antigovernment demonstrations, they are using a technological dragnet to target attendees of the protests.
item.dc:creator: Adam Satariano, Paul Mozur and Farnaz Fassihi
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Getty Images
item.media:description: Antigovernment protesters blocked a road last month in Tehran. Iran is using facial recognition and phone data to track and detain people involved in political opposition activities.

item.title: ‘Something Big Is Happening’ + A.I. Rocks the Romance Novel Industry + One Good Thing
item.description: “I do think we are reaching an inflection point in people’s feelings and senses about A.I. and where it’s going.”
item.dc:creator: Kevin Roose, Casey Newton, Whitney Jones, Rachel Cohn, Vjeran Pavic, Katie McMurran, Dan Powell, Elisheba Ittoop, Marion Lozano, Rowan Niemisto and Alyssa Moxley
item.media:credit: Photo Illustration by The New York Times; Photo: Getty Images

item.title: F.T.C. Chair Warns Apple Against Bias in Apple News
item.description: Andrew Ferguson of the F.T.C. said in a letter to Apple that it might be violating consumer protection law by stifling conservative speech in its news aggregation service.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Jim Wilson/The New York Times
item.media:description: Trump-appointed leaders of federal agencies have been using consumer protection laws to punish media and tech companies for perceived left-leaning bias.

item.title: Anthropic Is Valued at $380 Billion in New Funding Round
item.description: The artificial intelligence start-up raised another $30 billion, and its valuation more than doubled since its last funding round in September.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Anthropic was founded by Dario Amodei, right, and his sister, Daniela Amodei, who had parted ways with OpenAI.

item.title: Why Tech Giants Are Accused of Causing Social Media Addiction
item.description: In a series of landmark trials, plaintiffs are alleging that Meta, TikTok, Snap and YouTube caused personal injury through addictive products. Our technology reporter Cecilia Kang describes what’s at stake for tech giants and social media users.
item.dc:creator: Cecilia Kang, Christina Thornell, Laura Salaberry, Nikolay Nikolov and Thomas Vollkommer

item.title: Gail Slater Leaves Role as Justice Dept.’s Antitrust Chief
item.description: Her departure follows months of mounting tension over her division’s work to determine whether companies violated antitrust laws.
item.dc:creator: David McCabe
item.media:credit: Pete Kiehart for The New York Times
item.media:description: Abigail Slater was in the job as assistant attorney general for the antitrust division for roughly a year, after her confirmation in March.

item.title: Anthropic Donates $20 Million to Super PAC Operation to Counter OpenAI
item.description: Anthropic and OpenAI now have their own well-funded political groups that will square off in the midterm elections over artificial intelligence safety and regulation.
item.dc:creator: Theodore Schleifer
item.media:credit: Karsten Moran for The New York Times
item.media:description: Dario Amodei, a co-founder and chief executive of Anthropic, formerly worked at OpenAI.

item.title: Ford Will Make a Play for a Different Battery Market
item.description: The company, long focused on cars and trucks, plans to begin manufacturing large batteries used by utilities, data centers, other businesses and homeowners.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times
item.media:description: Ford’s closed battery plant in Glendale, Ky., which it plans to revamp to produce large storage batteries.

item.title: Laid-Off Battery Plant Workers Pin Blame on Ford, not Trump, for Lost Jobs
item.description: Ford Motor shut down a battery factory and laid off 1,600 workers after President Trump and Republicans gutted government support for electric vehicles.
item.dc:creator: Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Jon Cherry for The New York Times

item.title: Instagram Chief Says Social Media Is Not ‘Clinically Addictive’ in Landmark Trial
item.description: Adam Mosseri, who leads the Meta-owned app, testified that the company was careful to test features used by young people before releasing them.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Damian Dovarganes/Associated Press

item.title: OpenAI’s Biggest Challenge Is Turning Its A.I. Into a Cash Machine
item.description: The maker of ChatGPT hopes to triple its revenue in the coming year because it is planning to spend tens of billions of dollars. The clock is ticking.
item.dc:creator: Cade Metz and Mike Isaac
item.media:credit: Aaron Wojack for The New York Times
item.media:description: OpenAI’s offices in San Francisco. The start-up’s fast expansion means it has to quickly find new ways to make money.

item.title: Elon Musk Wants to Build an A.I. Satellite Factory on the Moon
item.description: In a meeting with employees at his company xAI, Mr. Musk revealed a vision for a facility that includes a giant catapult to launch his satellites into space.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Ryan Mac
item.media:credit: Eric Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Elon Musk told employees of xAI that he plans to put a factory on the moon as a steppingstone to colonizing Mars.

item.title: Ford Says Electric Vehicle Losses Will Continue for 3 More Years
item.description: Ford Motor reported a big loss for 2025 because of its troubled electric vehicle division, which it has significantly scaled back.
item.dc:creator: Neal E. Boudette
item.media:credit: Brett Carlsen for The New York Times
item.media:description: An F-150 Lightning electric pickup truck, which the company stopped producing last year, after federal tax credits for electric vehicles ended.

item.title: YouTube Argues It Isn’t Social Media in Landmark Tech Addiction Trial
item.description: The app said in opening statements that it was more of an entertainment platform. The lawsuit claims social media companies design products that cause personal injury.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Pete Marovich for The New York Times
item.media:description: Neal Mohan, left, the chief executive of YouTube, in 2024. The company’s lawyers argued in court on Tuesday that YouTube was an entertainment platform, not a social media platform.

item.title: A.I. Personalizes the Internet but Takes Away Control
item.description: The relentless addition of artificial intelligence in popular apps raises questions about what’s at stake. The answer: the future of the internet and its lifeblood, digital advertising.
item.dc:creator: Brian X. Chen
item.media:credit: Derek Abella

item.title: Meta and YouTube Created ‘Digital Casinos,’ Lawyers Argue in Landmark Trial
item.description: Opening statements began in a trial claiming social media companies design addictive products that cause personal injury.
item.dc:creator: Eli Tan and Cecilia Kang
item.media:credit: Stella Kalinina for The New York Times

item.title: A.I. Is Making Doctors Answer a Question: What Are They Really Good For?
item.description: Many physicians find chatbots threatening, but that doesn’t mean they’re giving up on medicine.
item.dc:creator: Gina Kolata
item.media:credit: Fabio Consoli

item.title: These A.I. Dreamers Don’t Fit the Stereotype
item.description: Young tech entrepreneurs in San Francisco are hoping to cash in, even as they wonder how artificial intelligence will affect society.
item.dc:creator: Guy Trebay
item.media:credit: Danielle Amy for The New York Times
item.media:description: The office of the San Francisco start-up Usul.

item.title: Washington Post C.E.O. Will Lewis Steps Down After Stormy Tenure
item.description: His departure came days after the company cut 30 percent of the staff. He will be replaced in the interim by Jeff D’Onofrio, the chief financial officer, the company said.
item.dc:creator: Benjamin Mullin, Katie Robertson and Erik Wemple
item.media:credit: Carlotta Cardana/Bloomberg
item.media:description: Will Lewis, the chief executive and publisher of The Washington Post, has stepped down, the company announced Saturday.

item.title: These Mathematicians Are Putting A.I. to the Test
item.description: Large language models struggle to solve research-level math questions. It takes a human to assess just how poorly they perform.
item.dc:creator: Siobhan Roberts
item.media:credit: Aurelien Bergot for The New York Times
item.media:description: Martin Hairer, a mathematician at the Swiss Federal Technology Institute of Lausanne. He splits his time between there and the Imperial College London.

item.title: After Merging xAI and SpaceX, Elon Musk Hopes He Can Win Over Wall Street
item.description: The billionaire’s decision to merge his A.I. start-up with his rocket company will test investors’ interest in giant combinations of unalike businesses.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger and Jack Ewing
item.media:credit: Meridith Kohut for The New York Times
item.media:description: SpaceX’s launchpad near Brownsville, Texas. In addition to rockets and satellites, Elon Musk’s company now includes artificial intelligence and social media businesses.
